<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_open:
```c
int lfs_file_open(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file, const char *path, int flags) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_open(%p, %p, \"%s\", %x)",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)file, path, (unsigned)flags);
    LFS_ASSERT(!lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    err = lfs_file_open_(lfs, file, path, flags);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_open -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_open:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
...
static int lfs_file_open_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file,
        const char *path, int flags) {
    static const struct lfs_file_config defaults = {0};
    int err = lfs_file_opencfg_(lfs, file, path, flags, &defaults);
    return err;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined each parameter of lfs_file_open (lfs, file, path, flags) and all called macros/functions used in the body. There are no assignments to any of the parameter variables, so none of the parameters themselves are modified (which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). Specific reasons:
- LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg) and LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg) macros expand to expressions that do not modify the lfs parameter or its pointer value (they evaluate cfg but only cast to void or return 0 in the provided definitions).
- LFS_TRACE only evaluates and casts the parameters for logging; it does not assign to them.
- LFS_ASSERT calls lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file). lfs_mlist_isopen takes its head parameter by value and iterates using a local pointer-to-pointer to that local copy (&head). It does not assign to the head parameter itself, so the head pointer parameter is not modified.
- The call err = lfs_file_open_(lfs, file, path, flags) simply forwards the parameters. Any modification of the object pointed to by file (or lfs) inside lfs_file_open_ is allowed by the rule (pointer targets may be modified); no modification of the pointer parameters themselves is present in the snippet shown.
- No assignments to path or flags are present; only a cast to unsigned for tracing.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that require investigation for Rule 17.8.
